content.webTitle: Radio review: Elisabeth Mahoney on Sunday Feature: Travelling the Great Divide – The New US-Mexico Border

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.bodyText: Sunday Feature: Travelling the Great Divide – The New US-Mexico border (Radio 3) was tremendous. Its strength was presenter Claudine LoMonaco, border correspondent for Arizona Public Radio, and a woman who knows this region well enough to source the most fascinating interviewees. "It's much more lethal than the Berlin wall ever was," said one contributor, noting more than 5,000 deaths here since 1995. LoMonaco spoke to a brisk-sounding 85-year old woman who lives in a remote spot 12 miles north of the border. She has had migrants walking across her land for years, and spoke about ﬁnding many near death, and some already dead, on her land. Most recently, she discovered the corpse of a 20-year-old young man, and remembered the detail of how inappropriate his shoes were: "They were shoes you would wear on a sidewalk." The report also portrayed a sense of crisis in Mexico, with the fast rise of drug-related violence. But it took time to look at the border's history – how easy-going things were in the 1950s, for example – and its future. "The only way you can stop a Mexican from moving from nothing to something," said one gloomy contributor, "is to make this country nothing."
